close_symbols: All return-code macros/enumeration used by OS_TranslatePath (i.e. the set of possible return values)
typedef/underlying type for the status/return codes (e.g. OS status enum or alias for int32)
explanation:
- OS_TranslatePath: The controlling expression in the if uses the value returned by this function (return_code). To decide if the test return_code == OS_SUCCESS is invariant we must know whether OS_TranslatePath can return different values depending on the input path (or other state) or if it always returns the same constant. This requires the implementation or formal specification of OS_TranslatePath (inputs that affect its return, side-effects, and possible outcomes).

- OS_SUCCESS: The if compares return_code to OS_SUCCESS. The exact definition/value of OS_SUCCESS is required to determine what the comparison means and whether that value is reachable/variable at run time.

- All return-code macros/enumeration used by OS_TranslatePath: Knowing OS_SUCCESS alone is not enough; we need the full set of possible return values (error/status macros or enum entries that OS_TranslatePath may produce) and the conditions under which each is returned. This lets us determine whether the equality test can ever evaluate true/false for different inputs or is effectively constant.

- typedef/underlying type for the status/return codes: The underlying type (e.g. an enum or typedef to int32) is needed to check for type/value semantics in the comparison (e.g. signed/unsigned or promoted types) and to ensure the comparison cannot be optimized/treated as invariant due to type width or constant folding.

(These symbols are the minimal set required to decide whether the controlling expression can vary at runtime. Other symbols in the call graph, such as OS_DirCreate_Impl or unit-test stub helpers, are not required to determine whether the if-condition itself is invariant.)
